J	Longo, GS; de la Cruz, MO; Szleifer, I				Longo, Gabriel S.; de la Cruz, Monica Olvera; Szleifer, Igal			pH-Controlled Nanoaggregation in Amphiphilic Polymer Co-networks	ACS NANO			English	Article						hydrogels; amphiphilic copolymer networks; responsive materials; nanoaggregation; drug delivery	DRUG-DELIVERY; SENSITIVE HYDROGELS; RESPONSIVE HYDROGELS; POLYELECTROLYTE GELS; ARTIFICIAL MUSCLES; CONTROLLED RELEASE; PHASE-TRANSITIONS; MOLECULAR DESIGN; GLUCOSE; EQUILIBRIUM	Domain formation and control In pH-responsive amphiphilic polymer co-networks are studied theoretically. Two different molecular architectures of the polymer network are considered, depending on whether the pH-sensitive motif Is borne by the hydrophobic or the hydrophilic monomer. When the hydrophobic polymer contains acidic groups, such chains form nanometric aggregates at acidic conditions, but they are found in a swollen state at alkaline pH. At intermediate pH, the nanoaggregation behavior of the hydrophobic polymer depends critically on the environment salt concentration. Moreover, our results indicate the presence of microphase separation Into domains of swollen and aggregated hydrophobic chains. If the hydrophilic polymer is the ionizable component of the network, the nanoaggregation of hydrophobic monomers is weakly dependent on the pH and salt concentration, and except at very low volume fraction, the aggregate is the most probable conformation of the network in the entire range of pH and salt concentration studied. The two different hydrogels display quantitatively similar swelling transition and apparent pk, but at the nanoscale, their behavior is qualitatively different. The spatial distribution of electric charge on the network as well as the local density of the different chemical species within the hydrogel can be controlled, as a function of pH and salt concentration, by the molecular architecture of the polymer network. These findings have relevance for applications in blomaterials and nanotechnology, In particular, In the design of oral delivery devices for the administration of hydrophobic	[Longo, Gabriel S.; de la Cruz, Monica Olvera] Northwestern Univ, Dept Mat Sci & Engn, Evanston, IL 60208 USA; [Szleifer, Igal] Northwestern Univ, Dept Biomed Engn, Evanston, IL 60208 USA; [Szleifer, Igal] Northwestern Univ, Dept Chem, Evanston, IL 60208 USA	Northwestern University; Northwestern University; Northwestern University	de la Cruz, MO (corresponding author), Northwestern Univ, Dept Mat Sci & Engn, 2170 Campus Dr, Evanston, IL 60208 USA.	m-olvera@northwestern.edu; igalsz@northwestern.edu	de la Cruz, Monica Olvera/X-2039-2019; Longo, Gabriel S./E-8823-2012; Longo, Gabriel S./S-5945-2019; Szleifer, Igal/B-6920-2009; de la Cruz, Monica Olvera/N-6359-2018	Longo, Gabriel S./0000-0001-8353-5163; Longo, Gabriel S./0000-0001-8353-5163; de la Cruz, Monica Olvera/0000-0002-9802-3627; Szleifer, Igal/0000-0002-8708-0335	NSF [DMR-0907781]; Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation [OPP1031734]; Division Of Materials Research [0907781] Funding Source: National Science Foundation	NSF(National Science Foundation (NSF)); Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation(Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation); Division Of Materials Research(National Science Foundation (NSF)NSF - Directorate for Mathematical & Physical Sciences (MPS))	M.O.C. acknowledges support from NSF (DMR-0907781). J	Rakovich, A; Nabiev, I; Sukhanova, A; Lesnyak, V; Gaponik, N; Rakovich, YP; Donegan, JF				Rakovich, Aliaksandra; Nabiev, Igor; Sukhanova, Alyona; Lesnyak, Vladimir; Gaponik, Nikolai; Rakovich, Yury P.; Donegan, John F.			Large Enhancement of Nonlinear Optical Response in a Hybrid Nanobiomaterial Consisting of Bacteriorhodopsin and Cadmium Telluride Quantum Dots	ACS NANO			English	Article						quantum dot; bacteriorhodopsin; purple membranes; D96N mutant; white membranes; hybrid material; nonlinear refractive index; nonlinear optical properties; Z-scan	Z-SCAN; CDTE NANOCRYSTALS; REFRACTIVE-INDEX; ABSORPTION; FILMS; MEMORIES; PROTEIN; CDSE	We report wavelength-dependent enormous enhancement of the nonlinear refractive index of wild-type bacteriorhodopsin in the presence of semiconductor quantum dots. The effect is strongest in the region just below the absorption edge of both constituents of this hybrid material and In samples that show strong Forster resonance energy transfer. We show that enhancements of up to 4000% can be achieved by controlled engineering of the hybrid structure involving variations of the molar ratio of the constituents. This new hybrid material with exceptional nonlinear properties will have numerous photonic and opto-electronic applications employing Its photothromic, energy transfer, and conversion properties. J	Marchi, AN; Saaem, I; Tian, JD; LaBean, TH				Marchi, Alexandria N.; Saaem, Ishtiaq; Tian, Jingdong; LaBean, Thomas H.			One-Pot Assembly of a Hetero-dimeric DNA Origami from Chip-Derived Staples and Double-Stranded Scaffold	ACS NANO			English	Article						structural DNA nanotechnology; molecular self-assembly; DNA origami; chip-synthesized oligonucleotides; synthetic biology; gene-synthesis; inkjet	GENE SYNTHESIS; FOLDING DNA; SHAPES; NANOSTRUCTURES; NANOTECHNOLOGY; AMPLIFICATION; MICROARRAY; FORMAMIDE	Although structural DNA nanotechnology, and especially scaffolded DNA origami, hold great promise for bottom-up fabrication of novel nanoscale materials and devices, concerns about scalability have tempered widespread enthusiasm. Here we report a single-pot reaction where both strands of double-stranded M13-bacteriophage DNA are simultaneously folded into two distinct shapes that then heterodimerize with high yield. The fully addressable, two-dimensional heterodimer DNA origami, with twice the surface area of standard M13 origami, formed in high yield (81% of the well-formed monomers undergo dimerization). We also report the concurrent production of entire sets of staple strands by a unique, nicking strand-displacement amplification (nSDA) involving reusable surface-bound template strands that were synthesized in situ using a custom piezoelectric inkjet system. The combination of chip-based staple strand production, double-sized origami, and high-yield one-pot assembly markedly increases the useful scale of DNA origami. Chemistry, Physical; Nanoscience & Nanotechnology; Materials Science, Multidisciplinary	Science Citation Index Expanded (SCI-EXPANDED)	Chemistry; Science & Technology - Other Topics; Materials Science	099KA	23281627				2022-12-19	WOS:000315618700006
J	Warner, M; Mauthoor, S; Felton, S; Wu, W; Gardener, JA; Din, S; Klose, D; Morley, GW; Stoneham, AM; Fisher, AJ; Aeppli, G; Kay, CWM; Heutz, S				Warner, Marc; Mauthoor, Soumaya; Felton, Solveig; Wu, Wei; Gardener, Jules A.; Din, Salahud; Klose, Daniel; Morley, Gavin W.; Stoneham, A. Marshall; Fisher, Andrew J.; Aeppli, Gabriel; Kay, Christopher W. M.; Heutz, Sandrine			Spin-Based Diagnostic of Nanostructure in Copper Phthalocyanine-C-60 Solar Cell Blends	ACS NANO			English	Article						EPR; organic solar cells; molecular aggregation; molecular orientation; DFT; XRD; texture analysis	THIN-FILMS; PARAMAGNETIC-RESONANCE; MOLECULAR-ORIENTATION; HETEROSTRUCTURES; DIANHYDRIDE; TRANSPORT; EPR	Nanostructure and molecular orientation play a crucial role in determining the functionality of organic thin films. In practical devices, such as organic solar cells consisting of donor-acceptor mixtures, crystallinity is poor and these qualities cannot be readily determined by conventional diffraction techniques, while common microscopy only reveals surface morphology. Using a simple nondestructive technique, namely, continuous-wave electron paramagnetic resonance spectroscopy, which exploits the well-understood angular dependence of the g-factor and hyperfine tensors, we show that in the solar cell blend of C-60 and copper phthalocyanine (CuPc)-for which X-ray diffraction gives no information-the CuPc, and by implication the C-60, molecules form nanoclusters, with the planes of the CuPc molecules oriented perpendicular to the film surface. This information demonstrates that the current nanostructure in CuPc:C-60 solar cells is far from optimal and suggests that their efficiency could be considerably increased by alternative film growth algorithms.	[Warner, Marc; Wu, Wei; Gardener, Jules A.; Morley, Gavin W.; Stoneham, A.
